thread.title: Devils still looking for first win after 5-3 loss to Caps
thread.title_full: Devils still looking for first win after 5-3 loss to Caps

title: Devils still looking for first win after 5-3 loss to Caps
text:
AP Devils defenseman John Moore (2) pushes off Washington Capitals defenseman Dmitry Orlov during the second period. 
WASHINGTON – The Devils and John Hynes will have to wait a couple more days for another shot at their first win of the season. 
Alex Ovechkin is mostly to blame for that after the Washington Capitals’ captain scored a highlight reel goal 6:33 into the third period to propel his team to a 5-3 victory Saturday night at Verizon Center. 
With the game tied at 2-2, Ovechkin raced in on the left wing and put the puck between his own skates while going wide around defenseman John Moore in the left circle before beating goaltender Keith Kinkaid high to the glove side. Marcus Johansson added a power-play goal with 7:16 remaining – assisted by Ovechkin – and Matt Niskanen scored an empty-net power play goal with 2:53 left to make it 5-2. 
Devils left wing Mike Cammalleri was credited with a goal with 1:21 remaining when Washington’s Jason Chimera accidentally put the puck in his own net, but it still added up to an 0-2-0 start for the Devils under Hynes, their rookie head coach. 
After being unhappy with how his team played in a 3-1 season-opening loss to Winnipeg Friday night at Prudential Center, Hynes decided to shake up his lineup. Out came defenseman Damon Severson and forwards Reid Boucher and Tuomo Ruutu and in went Eric Gelinas and forwards Brian O’Neill and Stefan Matteau. 
Hynes also decided to give backup Kinkaid the start instead of going to Cory Schneider on back-to-back nights to open the season. 
The Devils drew the first power play of the night when Evgeny Kuznetsov was sent off for hooking Jiri Tlusty at 10:24, but the Caps were the team to cash in with a shorthanded goal from Jason Chimera at 12:04. The Devils’ troubles began when Travis Zajac was pulled down and lost the puck in the neutral zone while his teammates were going for a change. Although they the puck out of their zone after that, they never really recovered. 
Chimera threw+ a pass in front intended for Justin Williams, but Devils right wing Jordin Tootoo reached in with his stick to deflect it away and redirected it past goaltender Keith Kinkaid instead. 
Defenseman Brooks Oprik made it 2-0 by beating Kinkaid between the pads from the slot at 14:32. 
Just when it appeared it was going to be a long night for the Devils, they answered only 22 seconds later with a goal from Adam Henrique. Tlusty made the pass from the right wing to Henrique alone in the slot and Henrique beat Braden Holtby over the right shoulder for his first goal of the season. Kyle Palmieri also assisted for the Montvale native’s first point as a Devil. Tlusty has a goal and an assist in the first two games of the season. 
The Devils got another chance on the power play when Sergey Kalinin drew a holding penalty on Sean Collins with 3:26 left in the period. This time they converted and tied the game with goal from Gelinas with 2:20 remaining in the first. 
Lee Stempniak got the puck back to Gelinas for a straight-on point shot that screamed in past Holtby on the stick side for his first of the season. 
The Capitals were the better team in the second period, outshooting the Devils 11-5 after being outshot 11-6 in the first. Kinkaid was sharp, though, and kept the score tied at 2. 
Kinkaid was particularly good during a Caps’ 5-on-3 power play for 1:38 following a Gelinas crosscheck with 5:21 left in the period and a Stempniak hold with 4:59 remaining, making five saves. His best was a blocker stop on T.J. Oshie’s backhand on a breakaway with 3:49 left. 
After exiting the box, Gelinas made a quick pass ahead to Adam Henrique to send him in on a shorthanded breakaway, but Holtby outwaited him and made a right toe save with 3:14 left. 
Briefs: O’Neill played in his first NHL game. The 27-year-Yale grad was acquired in Tuesday’s trade Los Angeles. … The Devils have the next two days off before hosting Nashville Tuesday night.
